name: Table of Contents
description: Navigation page listing all document sections with page numbers, using a structured hierarchical layout with dotted leaders connecting titles to page numbers. Placed immediately after the cover page or executive summary.

grid.columns: 3-14 (10 of 16 columns, centered with generous margins)

components: TOC heading: $heading-05 in $text-01, typically 'Contents' or 'Table of Contents'
Level-1 entries: $heading-03 in $text-01, bold, for main chapters/sections
Level-2 entries: $body-long-01 in $text-02, indented $spacing-07 from left edge
Page numbers: $body-short-01 in $text-01, right-aligned with dotted leader
Dotted leader line: $text-05 dots connecting title to page number
Section dividers: $spacing-05 (16px) gap between major section groups
Optional section icons or color accents for themed reports
rules: TOC always starts on its own page — use page-break-before: always
Maximum two levels of hierarchy — deeper nesting creates visual clutter on the TOC page
Level-1 entries use $heading-03 bold, level-2 entries use $body-long-01 regular — clear visual hierarchy
Page numbers right-aligned with dotted leader lines in $text-05 connecting to the entry text
Generous left/right margins (3-column inset on each side) — TOC should not feel dense
Group related sections with $spacing-05 gaps — visual clustering aids navigation
If TOC exceeds one page, continue on next page without repeating the TOC heading
Entry text should match the exact section titles used in the document body — no paraphrasing

printBehavior.pagePosition: page 2 or 3, after cover and optionally after executive summary

accessibilityNotes: Use <nav aria-label='Table of Contents'> wrapper — enables direct navigation to TOC
Each entry should be a link (<a href='#section-id'>) to the corresponding section heading
Page numbers are visual aids for print — in digital, the link itself provides navigation
Dotted leader lines must have aria-hidden='true' — purely decorative visual connector
antiPatterns: Never include more than two heading levels — deep nesting (3+) makes the TOC harder to scan than the document itself
Never omit page numbers — a TOC without page numbers is just an outline, not navigation
Never use the same type scale for all levels — visual hierarchy between levels is mandatory
Never crowd the TOC with body text margins — it needs generous whitespace to function as a scannable map
Never auto-generate a TOC that doesn't match actual section titles — mismatched titles destroy reader trust
